Caption: Fig. 1. Left: a traditional flow map of migration among 48 U.S. states. Right: a flow map of migrations between California and other states. This is to demonstrate that the traditional map can only handle very small data sets.
Table 1: A demonstrative example of flow variables.
Fig. 2: Lefta simple graph representing a set of flows among 12 locations. Righttwo regions (communities) constructed by a regionalization method.

Fig. 3: Comparison C of tw wo regionalizationn methods in parrtitio the counnty-to-county miggration data. The e result of the fine e-tu procedure is significantlyy better than the one by the spatially constrained average-linkkage clustering method m (ALK) alo one.

Fig. 4: The hierarchy of regions discovered by the regionalization method (with fine tuning) with the county-to-county migration data. The circle symbol for each region is positioned at the population centroid of that region and represents the within-region modularity (i.e., above- expectation migration). Region colors represent population density. County-level population density is shown in the same way but without county boundaries.
Fig. 5: Migration flow mapping with discovered regions. Leftan undirected flow map; Righta directed flow map.

Fig. 6: Multivariate flow mapping at the regional level. A self-organizing map (bottom left), parallel coordinate plot (bottom right), and a flow map (top right) are coordinated to present flow structure, multivariate information, and spatial patterns at the same time.

Fig. 7: User interactions. A section is made in the PCP on migration flows that have a relative high percentage of senior population (age between 65 and 69). It is strikingly clear in the flow map that senior (or retired) population tends to move to Florida (if they were from the north and east) or to Arizona if they were in the west part of the country.
